Key Point

The Addition Law of Probability - Simple Case

If two events \(A\) and \(B\) are mutually exclusive then 
\[\text{P}(A\cup B)=\text{P}(A)+\text{P}(B).\]

Key Point

The Addition Law of Probability - General Case

If two events are \(A\) and \(B\) then

\[\text{P}(A\cup B)=\text{P}(A)+\text{P}(B)-\text{P}(A\cap B).\]

If \(A\cap B= \emptyset\), i.e. \(A\) and \(B\) are mutually exclusive, then \(\text{P}(A\cap B)=\text{P}(\emptyset )=0\), and this general expression reduces to the simpler case.

This rule can be extended to three or more events, for example:

\[\text{P}(A\cup B\cup C)= \text{P}(A)+\text{P}(B)+\text{P}(C) - \text{P}(A\cap B)-\text{P}(A\cap C) -\text{P}(B\cap C)+\text{P}(A\cap B\cap C)\]

Example

Consider a pack of \(52\) playing cards. A card is selected at random.  What is the probability that the card is either a diamond or a ten? 

Solution

If \(A\) is the event a diamond is selected and \(B\) is the event a ten is selected then obviously \(\text{P}(A)=\dfrac{13}{52}\) and \(\text{P}(B)=\dfrac{4}{52}\). 

The intersection event \(A\cap B\) consists of only one member - the ten of diamonds - which gets counted twice hence \(\text{P}(A\cap B)=\dfrac{1}{52}\). 

Therefore \(\text{P}(A\cup B)=\dfrac{13}{52}+\dfrac{4}{52}-\dfrac{1}{52}=\dfrac{16}{52}\).
